Adding Occurrence-Specific Terms#

There are two items that are specific to occurrence records that need to be included:

  • At least one identifier, titled occurrenceID or catalogNumber or recordNumber

  • A value called basisOfRecord

The identifier ensures that each of your occurrence observations are unique, while basisOfRecord refers to how the occurrence was recorded. This is important for distinguishing individuals observed in the wild versus a museum specimen. This can also include things like camera traps and fossils. Here, we show (from the galah-python package) what options are available:

LivingSpecimen
MachineObservation
FossilSpecimen
HumanObservation
MaterialSample
PreservedSpecimen
Observation
MaterialCitation
Occurrence

Adding Unique Identifiers To Your Dataset#

If you don’t have any unique identifiers in your dataset, and want galaxias to generate ones for you, use the use_occurrences function:

>>> occ_dwca.use_occurrences(occurrenceID = True)
>>> occ_dwca.occurrences.head()

Your data will then look like this:

                           occurrenceID                  Species  Latitude  Longitude Collection_date
0  353a92c0-b05b-40c7-a3f8-b2add69054cc       Corymbia latifolia    -13.04     131.07       29/3/2022
1  8d74b9b2-6e07-4a2b-b888-fa368b6e304c     Eucalyptus tectifica    -13.04     131.07       13/9/2022
2  e54a8398-7607-4dd8-aa15-85365b3e546d           Banksia aemula    -33.60     150.72       15/8/2022
3  35a36bf8-9331-4337-921d-618caf871e14  Eucalyptus sclerophylla    -33.60     150.72       16/6/2022
4  5f0be755-3a96-42d5-bac1-ed0fac06b0dc        Persoonia laurina    -33.60     150.72      19/10/2022

Specifying A Value for basisOfRecord#

If you don’t have a basisOfRecord column in your dataset, you can use galaxias to add this column by including the basisOfRecord argument when you run use_occurrences():

>>> occ_dwca.use_occurrences(basisOfRecord = "HumanObservation")

Your data will then look like this:

                           occurrenceID                  Species  Latitude  Longitude Collection_date     basisOfRecord
0  6ae26c56-1737-4b05-9daf-f152690a368e       Corymbia latifolia    -13.04     131.07       29/3/2022  HumanObservation
1  9bb5f5a1-d7f4-4e3f-afcf-b7db73e28ab5     Eucalyptus tectifica    -13.04     131.07       13/9/2022  HumanObservation
2  2a11fe38-9796-4b15-a653-b6f7c042c078           Banksia aemula    -33.60     150.72       15/8/2022  HumanObservation
3  fc228bae-32d0-4bb3-b467-e9694c9da7e5  Eucalyptus sclerophylla    -33.60     150.72       16/6/2022  HumanObservation
4  ef446617-de46-4816-ac98-2f9bca62d641        Persoonia laurina    -33.60     150.72      19/10/2022  HumanObservation

Specifying columns for identifiers and basisOfRecord#

If your data already has these columns, but they do not have the required titles, you can instead specify a column of your data, and galaxias will rename it for you.

>>> occ_dwca.use_occurrences(basisOfRecord = occ_dwca.occurrences['<COLUMN-NAME>'],
...                          occurrenceID = occ_dwca.occurrences['<COLUMN-NAME>'])

Report After Adding Occurrence-Specific Data#

── Darwin Core terms ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

── All DwC terms ──

Matched 2 of 6 column names to DwC terms:

✓ Matched: occurrenceID, basisOfRecord
✗ Unmatched: Longitude, Collection_date, Species, Latitude

── Minimum required DwC terms ──

Type                       Matched term(s)    Missing term(s)
-------------------------  -----------------  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Identifier (at least one)  occurrenceID       -
Record type                -                  basisOfRecord
Scientific name            -                  scientificName
Location                   -                  decimalLatitude, decimalLongitude, geodeticDatum, coordinateUncertaintyInMeters, coordinatePrecision
Date/Time                  -                  eventDate

── Suggested workflow ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
To make your data Darwin Core compliant, use the following workflow:

df.use_occurrences()
df.use_scientific_name()
df.use_coordinates()
df.use_datetime()

Additional functions: use_locality()

Next: Scientific Names
